Chapter 1: The Master's Life and Times, Part 1: When the Great Master arrived at Baolin,

Wei, the Prefect of Shaozhou, whose personal name was Qu, together with officials, entered the mountains to invite the Master to come out. At the lecture hall of the Great Brahma Temple in the city, he expounded the Dharma for the assembly.

When the Master ascended the seat, more than thirty officials and prefects, more than thirty Confucian scholars, and over a thousand monks, nuns, Daoists, and laypeople made prostrations simultaneously, wishing to hear the essential teachings.
The Great Master said to the assembly:
Virtuous Friends!
The nature of enlightenment is originally pure. Simply use this mind to directly understand and attain Buddhahood.
Virtuous Friends!
Listen to Hui Neng's life and how he attained the Dharma.
Hui Neng's strict father was originally from Fan Yang. He was exiled to Lingnan and became a commoner of Xinzhou.
Unfortunately, his father passed away early.
The elderly mother, left alone with an orphan, moved to the South Sea. They were poor and destitute, selling firewood in the market.
At that time, a customer bought firewood and had it delivered to a guest house;
after the customer took it, Hui Neng received the money. As he was leaving the door, he saw a guest reciting a sutra.
As soon as Hui Neng heard the words of the sutra, his mind was enlightened, so he asked:
What sutra is the guest reciting?
The guest said:
The Diamond Sutra.
He asked again:
Where did you come from, carrying this sutra?
The guest said:
I came from Dongchan Temple in Huangmei County, Qizhou.
The temple is where the Fifth Patriarch, Great Master Ren, is teaching. There are over a thousand disciples;
I went there to pay homage and listen to this sutra.
The great master always encouraged monks and laypeople to simply uphold the Diamond Sutra, thereby directly realizing their own nature and attaining Buddhahood.

When Huineng heard this, he realized that he had karmic connections from the past. A guest then took ten ounces of silver and gave it to Huineng to provide clothing and provisions for his mother, instructing him to go to Huangmei to pay respects to the Fifth Patriarch.
After Huineng had settled his mother, he took his leave.
In less than thirty days, he arrived in Huangmei and paid respects to the Fifth Patriarch.
The patriarch asked:
Where are you from?
What do you seek?
Huineng replied:
I am a commoner from Xinzhou in the southern region. I have come from afar to pay respects to the master, only seeking to become a Buddha, not seeking anything else.
The patriarch said:
You are from the southern region, and you are a hunter from the barbarian tribes. How can you become a Buddha?
Huineng said:
Although people have north and south, the Buddha-nature is originally without north and south;
'The hunter's body is different from the master's, but what is the difference in Buddha-nature?'
The Fifth Patriarch wanted to continue speaking, but seeing that the disciples were all around, he told him to follow the assembly in doing work.
Hui Neng said:
'I inform the master that in my mind, wisdom always arises, not apart from its own nature, which is the field of blessings.
I do not know what kind of work the master wants me to do?'
The Patriarch said:
'This hunter has great spiritual capacity!
You should not speak again, go to the mill.'
Hui Neng went to the rear courtyard, where a practitioner assigned him to chop firewood and pound rice.
After more than eight months, the Patriarch suddenly saw Hui Neng one day and said:
'I thought your views could be used, but I was afraid that evil people would harm you, so I did not speak to you.
Do you know this?'
Hui Neng said:ğŸ”½'Yes, I know.'
'I also know the master's intention, and dare not go to the hall, lest people notice.'
One day the ancestor called all the disciples together and said:
The great matter of birth and death for people in the world, you all only seek blessings day after day, not seeking to escape the suffering of the sea of birth and death;
If your own nature is deluded, what blessings can save you?
You should each go and contemplate your own wisdom, take the nature of your own fundamental wisdom, and each compose a verse to present to me.
If you understand the great meaning, I will entrust you with the robe and Dharma as the sixth generation ancestor.
Go quickly, do not delay, thinking is not suitable;
A person who sees their nature must see it in the words.
If it is like this, even on a battlefield with revolving blades, one can see it.'
The sharp-witted ones received their share and withdrew, then said to each other:
'We don't need to concentrate our minds and compose verses to present to the master. What benefit is there?
The senior monk Shenxiu is currently the teaching master. It must be him who will obtain it.
We are just wasting our efforts composing verses.
' The other people heard this and all stopped thinking, saying:
'From now on we will rely on Master Xiu. Why bother composing verses?
' Shenxiu thought:
'The reason the others are not presenting verses is because I am their teaching master.
I must compose a verse and present it to the master. If I don't present a verse, how will the master know the depth of my understanding?

The intention of my presenting a verse is to seek the Dharma if it is good, and to find the ancestor if it is evil. It is the same as an ordinary mind, taking away the holy position, what is the difference?
If I don't present a verse, I will never obtain the Dharma.ğŸ”½It's very difficult!
It's very difficult!

In front of the Fifth Patriarch's hall, there is a three-room corridor, intending to invite the Venerable Lu Zhen to paint the transformation tableau of the Laá¹…kÄ Sutra and the bloodline chart of the Fifth Patriarch, to be passed down for worship.

After Shenxiu finished composing the verse, he wanted to present it several times. When he reached the front of the hall, his mind became confused and his whole body broke out in sweat. He could not present it.
For four days in total, he tried thirteen times to present the verse but failed.
Shenxiu then thought:
It would be better to write it on the corridor so that the Patriarch can see it. If he says it's good, I'll come out and bow, saying Shenxiu wrote it.
If he says it's not good, I've wasted several years in the mountains, receiving people's bows, and have not cultivated any further path.
That night at the third watch, without letting anyone know, he himself held a lamp and wrote the verse on the wall of the south corridor, presenting his understanding.
The verse said:
The body is the Bodhi tree, the mind is like a clear mirror stand.
From time to time diligently wipe it clean, do not let dust and dirt accumulate.
After HuÃ¬shÃ²u finished writing the verse, he returned to his room, and no one else knew about it.
HuÃ¬shÃ²u further thought:
If the Fifth Patriarch sees the verse tomorrow and is delighted, then I have a karmic connection with the Dharma;
if he says it is not suitable, then it is because I am deluded and my past karma is too heavy, and I am not worthy of receiving the Dharma.
The sage's intentions are difficult to fathom. In his room, he pondered, unable to sit or lie down in peace, until the fifth watch.
The Fifth Patriarch already knew that Shenxiu had entered the hall but had not attained insight into his own nature.
At daybreak, the Fifth Patriarch called out to Lu Gongfeng and said, 'Go to the south corridor wall and paint a picture.' Suddenly, he saw the verse and said,
'Lu Gongfeng, you don't need to paint anymore. It's a waste of your effort to come from afar.
The sÅ«tra says:
All forms and appearances are false and deceptive.
Just leave this verse here for people to recite and uphold.
By practicing according to this verse, one can avoid falling into the evil realms;
Relying on this verse in cultivation, there is great benefit.
He had his disciples burn incense and pay respects, and recited this verse completely, and then they could see their nature.
The disciples recited the verse, all exclaiming Excellent!
The Patriarch, at three in the morning, called Huixiu into the hall and asked:
Did you write this verse?
Huixiu said:
It is indeed what Huixiu wrote, not daring to falsely seek the Patriarch's position. I hope the Patriarch will have compassion and see if I have a little wisdom.
The Patriarch said:
The verse you wrote has not yet seen your original nature. You have only reached outside the door, not yet inside the door.
With such understanding, seeking unsurpassed enlightenment is completely unattainable.
For unsurpassed enlightenment, you must recognize your original mind and see your original nature, which is unborn and unceasing, in the present moment.
At all times, moment by moment, you will naturally see myriad phenomena without obstruction. One truth is all truths, and myriad realms are naturally thus.
The mind of suchness is precisely the true reality.
If you see in this way, it is precisely the intrinsic nature of the unsurpassed bodhi.
You may go for a day or two to contemplate, and then compose another verse to bring to me. I will examine it;
if your verse enters the gate, I will entrust you with the robe and Dharma.
' Shenxiu bowed and left.
After several more days, he was unable to compose a verse, and his mind was confused and uneasy, as if in a dream, neither sitting nor lying down in comfort.
' After two more days, a young boy passed by the pounding room, chanting the verse;
Huineng, upon hearing it once, immediately knew that this verse had not yet seen the intrinsic nature. Although he had not yet received instruction, he had already grasped the main point.
He then asked the young boy:
'What verse are you reciting?'
The young boy said:
'You barbarian hunter, you don't know. The great master said:
The great matter of birth and death for people in the world, I want to transmit the robe and Dharma, and have the disciples compose verses to come and see.
If they awaken to the great meaning, I will transmit the robe and Dharma to them as the sixth patriarch.

Elder Shenxiu wrote the verse on no-characteristics on the wall of the southern corridor. The great master had people recite it. By practicing according to this verse, one can avoid falling into evil paths;
By practicing according to this verse, there is great benefit.
' Huineng said:
'I also want to recite this, to create karmic affinity for the next life, elder!
I have been pounding rice for over eight months, and have never been able to go to the hall.
I hope the elder will lead me to the verse and pay respects.'
The boy led him to the verse and paid respects. Huineng said:
'I do not recognize characters, please, elder, read it for me.'
At that time, Zhang Dayu, the magistrate of Jiangzhou, then read it aloud.
After Huineng heard it, he said:
I also have a verse, hoping you will write it down for me.
The magistrate said:
You also compose verses?
That is a rare thing.
Hui Neng said to the magistrate:
If you want to study the unsurpassed enlightenment, you should not look down on beginners.
Even the lowest person may have the highest wisdom, and the highest person may have the lowest wisdom.
If you look down on people, you will have immeasurable and boundless faults.
The magistrate said:
You just recite the verse, and I will write it for you.
If you attain the Dharma, you must first save me.
Do not forget these words.
Hui Neng's verse said:ğŸ”½Originally, the Bodhi tree has no tree,
and the bright mirror also has no stand;ğŸ”½Originally, there is not a single thing,
so where can dust and dirt stick?
After writing this verse, the disciples were all shocked, and they all marveled, each saying to each other:
How strange!
Do not judge people by their appearance, how could you have him, a flesh-and-blood bodhisattva, for so long?
The Patriarch saw the crowd's astonishment and feared people would harm him, so he wiped the verse with his shoe and said:
He still hasn't seen his nature.
The crowd agreed.
The next day, the Patriarch secretly went to the rice-pounder's shed and saw Neng pounding rice with a stone on his waist. He said:
Those who seek the Way, for the Dharma they forget their bodies, it should be like this!
He then asked:
Is the rice cooked yet?
Hui Neng said:
The rice has been cooked for a long time, it just needs sifting.
The Patriarch struck the rice-pounder three times with his staff and left.
Hui Neng immediately understood the Patriarch's meaning, and at the third watch he entered the room;
the Patriarch used his kasaya to surround him, not letting people see, and explained the Diamond Sutra for him.
When he reached one should give rise to the mind without abiding in anything, Huineng suddenly had great enlightenment, and all myriad dharmas were not apart from his own nature.
He then said to the Patriarch:
How could it be that one's own nature is originally pure?
How could it be that one's own nature is originally unborn and unceasing?
How could it be that one's own nature is originally complete?
How could it be that one's own nature is originally unmoving?
How could it be that one's own nature can give rise to myriad dharmas?
The Patriarch knew that Huineng had realized his original nature and said:
If one does not recognize one's original mind, studying the Dharma is of no benefit.
If one recognizes one's original mind and sees one's original nature, one is then called a great man, a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha.
At the third watch, he received the Dharma and everyone did not know. He then transmitted the sudden teaching and the robe and bowl, saying:
You are the sixth patriarch. Take good care of yourself, widely liberate sentient beings, spread it in the future, and do not let it be cut off.
Listen to my verse:
The seeds of sentient beings come down, the cause is the ground, the fruit is born again.
The insentient have long been without seeds, without nature, and also without birth.
The Patriarch said again:
In the past, when the Great Master Bodhidharma first came to this land, people did not believe him, so he transmitted this robe as a symbol of faith, to be passed down from generation to generation.
The Dharma is transmitted from mind to mind, causing everyone to awaken and understand on their own.
From ancient times, the Buddhas have only transmitted the fundamental nature, and the teachers have secretly entrusted the fundamental mind to each other.
The robe is a source of contention, so you should not transmit it.
If you transmit this robe, your life will be like a hanging thread.
You must leave quickly, lest people harm you.
Hui Neng said:
Where will you go?
The Patriarch said:
Stay when you encounter a worthy, hide when you meet a gathering.
At the third watch, Hui Neng took the robe and bowl and said:
'You are originally from the south and have never known the mountain roads here, how could you get out of the river mouth?'
The Fifth Patriarch said:
'You don't need to worry, I will send you myself.
' The patriarch escorted him all the way to the Jiujiang post station.
The patriarch told him to board the boat, and the Fifth Patriarch himself took the oars.
Hui Neng said:
'Please have the patriarch sit.
I should be the one rowing the oars.
' The patriarch said:
'It should be I who ferries you across.
' Hui Neng said:
'When confused, the teacher ferries across; when enlightened, one ferries oneself.
The name 'ferry' is the same, but the usage is different.

Hui Neng was born in the borderlands, my speech is not correct, I have received the teacher's transmission of the Dharma, and now I have attained enlightenment, I should only use my own nature to ferry myself across.'
The patriarch said:
'So it is, so it is!
From now on, the Buddha Dharma will be greatly spread by you.
Three years after you leave, I will pass away.
You should now go well and make effort towards the south.
It is not suitable to speak hastily, as the Buddha Dharma is difficult to arise.
Hui Neng, having taken leave of the Patriarch, set out southwards.
After two months, he reached Dayu Pass. The Fifth Patriarch returned and did not go up to the hall for several days.
The assembly suspected and asked:
'Is the Venerable free from illness and affliction?'
He said:
'There is no illness.
The robe and Dharma have already gone south.'
They asked:
'Who transmitted it?'
He said:
'One who is capable has obtained it.'
The assembly then knew.
Several hundred people chased after him, wanting to snatch the robe and alms bowl.
A monk surnamed Chen, named Hui Ming, was previously a fourth-rank general. He was by nature coarse and rough, and went to great lengths to seek the Dharma.
He was the first among the group to catch up with Hui Neng.
Hui Neng placed the robe and alms bowl on a rock and said:
'This robe symbolizes faith. Can it be struggled over by force?
You can hide in the grass and bushes.
When Huiming arrived, he tried to lift it but it did not move, so he called out:ğŸ”½Practitioner!
Practitioner!
I come for the Dharma, not for clothes.
Hui Neng then came out and sat on a flat rock.
Huiming bowed and said:
I hope the practitioner will explain the Dharma for me.
Hui Neng said:
Since you have come for the Dharma, you should clear away all thoughts and not give rise to a single thought.
I will explain the Dharma for you.
Huiming was silent for a while.
Hui Neng said:
Not thinking of good, not thinking of evil, right at that moment, what is your original face, Upasaka Ming?
Huiming was greatly enlightened at these words.
He asked again:
Apart from the secret words and secret meanings you have spoken, are there any other secret meanings?
Hui Neng said:
What I have explained to you is not secret.
If you turn and reflect, the secret lies within you.
Ming said:
Although I was at Huangmei, I still had not realized my own face.
Now, having been instructed, it is like a person drinking water, knowing for themselves if it is cold or warm.
The practitioner now is my teacher.
Hui Neng said:
If it is like this for you, then I and you have the same teacher at Huangmei. Take good care of yourself.
Ming asked again:
Where will I go from now on?
Hui Neng said:
Stop when you meet Yuan, stay when you meet Meng.
Ming took his leave and returned to the foot of the mountain, telling the pursuers:
We climbed to the highest peak, but there was no trace of him. We should search for him by another path.
The pursuers all agreed.
Later, Hui Ming changed his name to Dao Ming to avoid using the same character as his teacher's.
Later, Hui Neng arrived at Caoxi, but was again pursued by evil people.
He then fled to the hunting party for fifteen years, during which time he would preach the Dharma as appropriate to the hunters.
The hunters always made him guard the traps, and whenever he saw living creatures, he would release them all.
Whenever it was mealtime, he would send vegetables to be cooked in the meat pot.
When asked about it, he would reply:
Just eat the vegetables by the meat.
One day, he thought:
The time has come to spread the Dharma, I cannot remain in hiding forever.
He then went to Fa-xing Temple in Guangzhou, where he met Dharma Master Yin-zong lecturing on the Nirvana Sutra.
At that time, the wind was blowing the banner, and a monk said:
The wind is moving.
Another monk said:
The banner is moving.
They argued without end.
Hui-neng stepped forward and said:
It is not the wind moving, it is not the banner moving, it is the mind of the good people moving.
The entire assembly was shocked.
Yin-zong invited him to the upper seat and questioned him on the profound meaning.
Seeing that Huineng's words were concise and his principles were correct, not relying on written texts, Zong said:
The practitioner must be no ordinary person.
I have long heard that the robe and Dharma of Huangmei are coming south. Could the practitioner be the one?
Huineng said:
I dare not.
Zong then bowed and invited him to show the robe and alms bowl to the assembly.
Zong further asked:
How did Huangmei entrust it to you?
Huineng said:
There is nothing to entrust;
I only discuss seeing the nature, not discussing meditation, concentration, and liberation.
Zong said:
Why not discuss meditation, concentration, and liberation?
Huineng said:
These are two dharmas, not the Buddha Dharma.
The Buddha Dharma is the Dharma of non-duality.
Zong further asked:
What is the Buddha Dharma of non-duality?
Huineng said:
The Dharma Master lectures on the Nirvana Sutra, clarifying Buddha-nature, which is the non-dual Dharma of Buddhism.
Just as the Bodhisattva Gao Guai De Wang said to the Buddha:
Do those who commit the four grave offenses, commit the five heinous crimes, and are icchantikas, have their wholesome roots and Buddha-nature severed?
The Buddha said:
There are two kinds of wholesome roots:
one is permanent, the other is impermanent. Buddha-nature is neither permanent nor impermanent, therefore it is not severed, and is called non-dual.
One is wholesome, the other is unwholesome. Buddha-nature is neither wholesome nor unwholesome, this is called non-dual.
The aggregates and elements, ordinary beings see them as dual, but the wise understand their nature to be non-dual. The nature of non-duality is precisely Buddha-nature.
Upon hearing this, Yin Zong joyfully joined his palms and said:
My lecturing on the sutra is like rubble;
your discussion of the Dharma is like true gold.
Thus he shaved Hui Neng's head and wished to serve as his teacher.
Hui Neng then opened the Dharma gate of East Mountain under the Bodhi tree.
Hui Neng obtained the Dharma at East Mountain, enduring hardships to the end of his life.

Today, he is able to be in the same assembly as the envoy, officials, monks and nuns, and laypeople, all of whom are not without karmic connections from many eons. They have also made offerings to the Buddhas in past lives and planted wholesome roots together, only then being able to hear the causes of the above sudden teachings and obtaining the Dharma.
The teachings are transmitted by the sages of the past, not the wisdom of Hui Neng himself.
Those who wish to hear the teachings of the sages should each purify their minds, hear and remove their own doubts, just as the sages of the past did not differ.
The assembly heard the Dharma, joyfully made prostrations, and withdrew.
On the second day, Envoy Wei requested further teachings.
The master ascended the seat and told the great assembly:
Contemplate the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ with a pure mind.
He also said:
Good friends!
The wisdom of enlightenment and prajÃ±Ä is originally possessed by all people in the world;
It is only because the mind is deluded that one cannot awaken on one's own, and one must rely on a great good and wise advisor to point out and reveal one's nature.

Know that the nature of the buddhas in deluded people and wise people is originally without distinction; it is only because of the difference in delusion and awakening that there are the deluded and the wise.
I will now explain the Dharma of MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ for you, enabling each of you to attain wisdom.
Listen attentively with a sincere mind!
I will explain it for you.
Good friends!
People spend their whole lives reciting prajÃ±Ä with their mouths, yet they do not recognize the prajÃ±Ä of their own nature, just like talking about food without getting full.
The mouth merely speaks of emptiness, and for myriad eons one does not get to see one's nature, which is ultimately of no benefit.
Good friends!
MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is a Sanskrit term meaning great wisdom that reaches the other shore.
This requires mental practice, not just verbal recitation.
Verbal recitation without mental practice is like an illusion, a transformation, dew, or lightning;
Verbal recitation with mental practice aligns mind and mouth. The inherent nature is Buddha, apart from nature there is no separate Buddha.
What is meant by mahÄ?
MahÄ means great.

The mind's measure is vast like empty space, without boundaries, and also without squareness, roundness, size, or smallness, and is neither blue, yellow, red, or white, and also has no above, below, long, or short, and also has no anger or joy, no right or wrong, no good or evil, and has no head or tail.
All Buddha lands are the same as empty space.
The wondrous nature of worldly people is originally empty, and not a single dharma can be obtained.
One's own nature is true emptiness, and it is also like this.
Good and virtuous friends!ğŸ”½Do not hear me speak of emptiness and then immediately become attached to emptiness.
First, do not become attached to emptiness. If you sit in stillness with an empty mind, you will become attached to indeterminate emptiness.
Good friends!

The sky of the world can contain all the forms of myriad things, the sun, moon, and stars, mountains, rivers, and the earth, springs, streams, grasses, trees, forests, evil people and good people, evil dharmas and good dharmas, the heavens and hells, all the great oceans, Mount Sumeru, and all the mountains, are all in the sky.
The nature of the world is empty, and it is also like this.
Good friends!
The nature of oneself can contain myriad dharmas, which is great. Myriad dharmas are within the nature of all people.
If one sees all people, evil and good, and does not take or abandon them, and is also not attached to them, the mind is like empty space, and is called great. Therefore, it is called mahat.
Good friends!
Deluded people speak with their mouths, while the wise act with their minds.
There are also deluded people who sit in empty stillness, thinking nothing at all, and call themselves great.
This kind of person cannot be spoken to, because of their wrong views.
Good friends!
The mind's scope is vast and pervades the Dharma realm. When the function is clearly understood, one can know everything.
All is one, and one is all.
Coming and going freely, with no obstruction in the mind's essence, this is prajÃ±Ä.
Good friends!
All prajÃ±Ä-wisdom arises from one's own nature and does not come from outside.
Do not misunderstand and call it the true nature's self-function. One truth is all truths.
The mind's vast matter does not follow the small path.

Do not constantly speak of emptiness with the mouth while not cultivating this practice in the mind. It is like an ordinary person calling themselves a king, which is ultimately impossible. They are not my disciples.
Good friends!
What is called prajÃ±Ä?
PrajÃ±Ä means wisdom in Tang.
In all places and at all times, moment by moment not being foolish and always practicing wisdom, this is the practice of prajÃ±Ä.
A moment of delusion is the extinction of prajÃ±Ä, a moment of wisdom is the arising of prajÃ±Ä.
The deluded people of the world do not see prajÃ±Ä, they speak of prajÃ±Ä with their mouths, but their minds are always deluded.
They always say:
'I cultivate prajÃ±Ä.'
Thinking of emptiness moment by moment, they do not recognize true emptiness.
PrajÃ±Ä has no form or appearance, the mind of wisdom is it.
If one understands in this way, it is called the wisdom of prajÃ±Ä.
What is called pÄramitÄ?
This is a word from the Western Regions, meaning 'reaching the other shore' in Tang, understanding the meaning and being free from arising and ceasing.
Attachment to objects gives rise to arising and ceasing, like water with waves, which is called 'this shore';
Being free from objects, there is no arising or ceasing, like water always flowing through, which is called 'the other shore,' thus it is called pÄramitÄ.
Good and virtuous friends!
The deluded mouth recites, when reciting, there is falsity and non-existence.
If thought after thought is practiced, this is called true nature.
One who realizes this Dharma is one of prajÃ±Ä;
One who cultivates this practice is one of prajÃ±Ä.
Not cultivating is ordinary;
One thought of cultivation, one's own body is equal to the Buddha.
Good and virtuous friend!
Ordinary beings are buddhas, afflictions are bodhi.
The previous thought of delusion is an ordinary being, the subsequent thought of awakening is a buddha.
The previous thought of attachment to objects is afflictions, the subsequent thought of detachment from objects is bodhi.
Good and virtuous friend!
MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ is the most revered, the highest, and the foremost. It is without abiding, without going, and without coming. The buddhas of the three times emerge from within it.
One should use great wisdom to shatter the five aggregates, afflictions, and dusts of karma.
Cultivating in this way, one will certainly accomplish the Buddha Way and transform the three poisons into precepts, concentration, and wisdom.
Good and virtuous friend!
In this Dharma gate of mine, from one prajÃ±Ä, eighty-four thousand wisdoms arise.
Why is it so?
For the people of the world have eighty-four thousand afflictions.
If there were no afflictions, wisdom would always manifest and not depart from its intrinsic nature.
One who awakens to this Dharma is without thought, without memory, without attachment, and does not give rise to deception.
Using one's own true suchness nature, with wisdom and insight, not grasping or rejecting any dharma, one then sees one's nature and attains Buddhahood.
Good and virtuous friends!

If one wishes to enter the profound Dharma realm and the prajÃ±Ä samÄdhi, one must cultivate prajÃ±Ä practices and recite the Diamond PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra, then one will be able to see one's nature.
One should know that the merit of this sÅ«tra is immeasurable and boundless, clearly praised within the sÅ«tra, and cannot be fully described.
This Dharma door is the supreme vehicle, taught for those of great wisdom, taught for those of superior faculties.
Those of inferior faculties and inferior wisdom will give rise to disbelief upon hearing it.
Why is it so?
It is like a great dragon raining on JambudvÄ«pa, where cities and villages are all flooded like floating jujube leaves.
If it rains on the great ocean, it neither increases nor decreases.
If a person of the Great Vehicle or the supreme vehicle hears the teaching of the Diamond Sutra, their mind will open up and they will understand.
Therefore, it is known that the inherent nature itself has the wisdom of prajÃ±Ä. Using one's own wisdom, always contemplating and illuminating, one does not rely on written words.

It is like rainwater, which does not come from the heavens. It is originally the dragon's ability to bring it forth, causing all sentient beings, all grasses and trees, and all with and without sentience, to all be moistened.
The myriad streams and rivers return to the great ocean, merging into one essence.
The inherent wisdom of prajÃ±Ä in sentient beings is also like this.
Good and virtuous friends!
If people of small capacity hear this sudden teaching, it is like grasses and trees with small roots and capacities. If they are hit by heavy rain, they all fall over by themselves and cannot grow.
It is the same for those with small capacities.

I have a verse on the formless, which you should all recite. Whether at home or leaving home, just practice according to this.

Speaking of the universal and the mind's universal, like the sun in the sky,
Only transmitting the Dharma of seeing the nature, leaving the world to destroy false doctrines.

Neither evil nor correct should be used; purity reaches the end.

The pure mind is within delusion; only the correct has no three hindrances.
If worldly people cultivate the Way, it does not interfere with anything.
Always see one's own faults; then it corresponds with the Way.
Each type of form has its own Way; they do not obstruct each other.
Separating from the Way to seek the Way elsewhere, one will never see the Way in one's lifetime.
Strive through one's life, but in the end one still regrets.
If one wishes to see the true Way, practicing the correct is the Way.
If one's mind lacks the Way, one will not see the Way by practicing in the dark.

If one sees the faults of others, one's own faults are actually on the left.
Others are not me, I am not others, I am not myself, and there are no faults.
But only the mind that turns away from faults, removes afflictions and breaks through,
Hates and loves do not concern the mind, stretching out both legs and lying down.
If you want to transform others, you must have skillful means,
Do not let them have doubts, this is the manifestation of one's own nature.
The Buddha's teachings are in the world, not apart from worldly awakening,
Leaving the world to seek enlightenment is like seeking rabbit horns.
Right view is called supramundane, wrong view is mundane,
Wrong and right are all struck away, the nature of enlightenment is still present.
This verse is the sudden teaching, also called the great Dharma boat,
Deluded, hearing the sutra for eons, enlightened, in an instant.
The master continued:
Now, at the Great Brahma Temple, I expound this sudden teaching, universally wishing that all sentient beings in the Dharma realm, upon hearing it, see their nature and attain Buddhahood.
At that time, Governor Wei and the officials, clergy, and laypeople, upon hearing the master's teachings, all had insights.

Excellent!

Questioning Questions, Part Three On the first day, Regional Inspector Wei held a great assembly and offered a vegetarian feast for the master.
After the feast, the regional inspector invited the master to ascend the seat. Together with the officials, scholars, and laypeople, they respectfully bowed twice and asked:
Disciple has heard that the Venerable's teachings are truly inconceivable.
Now I have a few doubts. I wish the great compassionate one would specially explain them for me.
The master said:
If you have doubts, ask them. I shall explain for you.
Governor Wei said:
Is what the Venerable has been teaching not the fundamental purport of Great Master Bodhidharma?
The master said:
Yes.
The governor said:
Disciple has heard that:
Bodhidharma first taught in the Liang dynasty. Emperor Wu asked:ğŸ”½What is the ultimate meaning of the holy truths?
'In my life, I have built temples, ordained monks, distributed offerings, and held vegetarian feasts. What merits do I have?'
Bodhidharma said:
'In truth, there are no merits.'
The disciples, not yet understanding this principle, asked the master to explain it.
The master said:
'In truth, there are no merits. Do not doubt the words of the sages.
Emperor Wu's mind is biased, not knowing the true Dharma.
Building temples, ordaining monks, distributing offerings, and holding vegetarian feasts are called seeking blessings, but blessings cannot be considered merits.
Merits are in the Dharma body, not in cultivating blessings.'
The master further said:
'Seeing one's nature is merit, and equality is virtue.
Moment by moment, without obstruction, always seeing one's original nature, true and wondrous function, is called merit and virtue.
Humility in the inner mind is merit, and external conduct in propriety is virtue.
Establishing myriad dharmas based on one's nature is merit, and the mind essence free from thought is virtue.
Not departing from one's own nature is merit, applying without attachment is virtue.

If one seeks the Dharma body of merit and virtue, one should rely on this to create true merit and virtue.ğŸ”½If one cultivates merit and virtue, one's mind will not be light, and one will always practice universal respect.
If one always looks down on others, one's self-view is not severed, and one has no merit;
If one's nature is false and unreal, one has no virtue.
It is because one is arrogant and always looks down on everyone.
Good and virtuous friend!
Moment-to-moment uninterruptedness is merit, and the practice of the mind being straightforward is virtue.
Cultivating one's nature is merit, and cultivating one's body is virtue.
Good and virtuous friend!
Merit and virtue must be seen within one's own nature, and are not sought through giving and making offerings.
Therefore, merit and virtue are distinguished.
Emperor Wu did not understand the truth, and it is not my patriarch's fault.
The prefect asked again:
The disciple always sees monks and laypeople reciting Amitabha Buddha's name, wishing to be reborn in the Western Pure Land.

Please resolve our doubts.
The master said:
Listen well, I will explain for you.
The World-Honored One, while in the city of Shravasti, spoke of the Western Pure Land to guide beings.
The sutra text is clear, not far from here.
If we discuss it in terms of appearances, it is 108,000 li away, which refers to the ten evils and eight wrong paths in the body, indicating it is far.
Speaking of it as far is for those of lower faculties, speaking of it as near is for those of higher wisdom.
People are of two kinds, the Dharma is not of two kinds.
Delusion and enlightenment differ, and views have slow and fast.
Deluded people recite the Buddha's name and seek rebirth there, enlightened people purify their own minds.
Therefore the Buddha said:
'According to the purity of one's mind, the Buddha land is pure.'
People in the East, if the mind is pure, there is no sin.
Even if the people of the West have impure minds, they still have faults.
The people of the East commit sins but think of the Buddha and seek to be reborn in the West.
The people of the West commit sins but think of the Buddha and seek to be reborn in what country?
Foolish people do not understand their own nature and do not recognize the Pure Land in their own bodies, wishing to go east or west.
The enlightened person sees everywhere as the same, so the Buddha said:
Wherever one stays, one is always at ease.
If the mind of the lord of the prefecture is without unwholesomeness, the West is not far from here.
If one harbors an unwholesome mind, it is difficult to be reborn by thinking of the Buddha.
Now I advise the good and wise to first eliminate the ten evils and practice the ten thousand, and later eliminate the eight perversions and surpass the eight thousand.
Moment by moment, seeing one's nature, always practicing straightforwardness, reaching in the time it takes to snap one's fingers, one will see Amitabha.
If the lord of the prefecture just practices the ten wholesome deeds, why bother to further wish to be reborn?
If one does not stop the mind of the ten evils, what Buddha will come to welcome one?
If you realize the sudden Dharma of no birth, you will see the Western Land is only a moment away.
If you do not realize mindfulness of the Buddha and seek rebirth, how can you reach your destination on a long road?
I will move the Western Land to a moment for all of you, and you will see it right before your eyes.
Do you each wish to see it?
The assembly bowed their heads and said:
If we see it here, why do we still wish to be reborn?
We only wish that the Venerable would have compassion and manifest the Western Land so that we may all see it.
The master said:
Great assembly!
The human body is a city, and the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body are the gates. Outside there are five gates, and inside there is the mental gate.
The mind is the ground, and nature is the king.
The king resides above the ground of the mind. When the nature is present, the king is present. When the nature departs, the king has nothing.
When the nature is present, the body exists. When the nature departs, the body perishes.
The Buddha is made within the nature, do not seek outside the body.
The deluded nature is the sentient being, the awakened nature is the Buddha.
Compassion is Avalokitesvara, joy and equanimity are Mahasthamaprapta, purity is Shakyamuni, and uprightness is Amitabha.
Self-identity is Mount Sumeru, desire is the ocean, afflictions are the waves, poison and harm are the evil dragons, falsehood is the ghosts and spirits, and dust and toil are the fish and turtles.
Greed and anger are hell, and delusion is the animal realm.
Good friends!
Always practice the ten wholesome deeds, and heaven will be reached.
Remove self-identity, and Mount Sumeru will collapse;
Remove desire, and the ocean will dry up;
Without afflictions, the waves will cease;
Remove poison and harm, and fish and dragons will be gone.
The enlightened nature above one's own mind is the Tathagata emitting great light;
Externally illuminating the six sense doors and purifying them, it can destroy the six desire heavens;
Internally illuminating one's own nature, the three poisons will be removed;
The offenses of hell and so forth will be instantly extinguished, and the inside and outside will be clearly penetrated, no different from the Western Paradise.

Excellent!
They proclaimed:

The master said:

The verses say:

Kindness is filial piety in serving parents, righteousness is mutual compassion between superiors and inferiors,
Humility is harmony between the noble and humble, forbearance is the absence of chaos in the face of many evils,
If one can drill wood to produce fire, red lotuses will surely grow in muddy water.
Bitter words are good medicine, contrary ears must be loyal words,
Repenting of mistakes will surely produce wisdom, protecting shortcomings in the heart is not virtuous.
Daily practice of benefiting others, attaining the Way is not due to giving money,

Listen to the practice based on this, the Western Paradise is right before your eyes.
The master said again:

The master addressed the assembly, saying:
Good friends!

The master addressed the assembly, saying:

In my Dharma gate, from the past until now, we first establish non-thought as the principle, non-form as the essence, and non-abiding as the basis.

In the world, whether it is good or evil, beautiful or ugly, even to enemies and loved ones, when there are words that prick and deceive, one should regard them all as empty, not thinking of retaliation, and in every thought not thinking of the objects in front.

Externally, being free from characteristics is Chan, and internally, being undisturbed is concentration.
Externally Chan and internally concentration, this is Chan concentration.
The Bodhisattva Precepts Sutra says:

Good and virtuous friends!
In every thought, see your fundamental nature as pure, cultivate your own practice, and accomplish Buddhahood on your own.

At the sixth time of repentance, the Great Master saw that Guang Shao and people from all directions had gathered in the mountains to listen to the Dharma. He then ascended the seat and said to the assembly:

Each follow my words and recite together:

Vow to liberate sentient beings, which are as limitless as one's own mind; vow to sever afflictions, which are as limitless as one's own mind; vow to study the Dharma gates, which are as inexhaustible as one's own nature; vow to attain the unsurpassed Buddhahood, which is as ultimate as one's own nature.
Good and virtuous friends!
Hasn't everyone said, 'Vow to liberate sentient beings, which are as limitless as one's own mind'?
Saying this is not the same as what Huineng would say.
Good friends!
The sentient beings in the mind are the deluded mind, the deceptive mind, the unwholesome mind, the jealous mind, the malicious mind, and so forth - all such minds are sentient beings.
Each must be self-nature and self-liberated, which is called true liberation.
What is meant by self-nature and self-liberation?
It is using right view to liberate the sentient beings of wrong views, afflictions, and ignorance in one's own mind.
Having right view, one uses the wisdom of prajÃ±Ä to break through the sentient beings of ignorance and delusion, each liberating themselves.
When wrong comes, right liberates; when delusion comes, enlightenment liberates; when ignorance comes, wisdom liberates; when evil comes, goodness liberates.
Liberating in this way is called true liberation.
Furthermore, vowing to eliminate afflictions without bound, using the wisdom of self-nature prajÃ±Ä to remove false thoughts and delusions is it.
Moreover, in vowing to study the inexhaustible Dharma gates, one must see one's own nature and always practice the true Dharma. This is called true study.

Moreover, in vowing to accomplish the unsurpassed Buddha Way, since one is always able to lower one's mind and practice the true and proper, free from delusion and enlightenment, one always gives rise to prajÃ±Ä.
Eliminating the true and eliminating the false, one sees the Buddha-nature, and the Buddha Way is accomplished right on the spot.
Always contemplating and practicing is the power of this vow.
Good and virtuous friend!
Now that the four great vows have been made, I will further bestow the formless precepts of the Three Refuges upon you, good and virtuous friend!
Good and virtuous friend!
Take refuge in enlightenment, the most honored of two-legged beings.
Take refuge in correctness, the most honored of those free from desire.
Take refuge in purity, the most honored among the assembly.

From this day forth, take enlightenment as your teacher, and do not take refuge in demons or non-Buddhist paths. With the three jewels of your own nature always self-evidently present, I encourage you, good and virtuous friend, to take refuge in the three jewels of your own nature.
Buddha means enlightenment.
Dharma means correctness.
Sangha means purity.

When one's own mind takes refuge in enlightenment, delusion and confusion do not arise. With few desires and contentment, one can avoid wealth and desires. This is called the Honored One with Two Feet.

When one's own mind takes refuge in correctness, moment by moment there is no wrong view. Because there is no wrong view, there is no arrogance of self-importance, greed, and attachment. This is called the Honored One Free from Desire.
When one's own mind takes refuge in purity, all the realms of afflictions, desires, and love are inherently unstained and unattached. This is called the Honored One in the Assembly.
If one cultivates this practice, it is taking refuge in oneself.
Ordinary people who do not understand it receive the precepts of the Three Refuges from day to night.
If one says they take refuge in the Buddha, where is the Buddha?
If one does not see the Buddha, what do they rely on to take refuge? Their words become false.
Good and virtuous friends!
Each of you should observe yourselves and not mistakenly apply your minds.
The sutra text clearly states to take refuge in the Buddha oneself, not to take refuge in another Buddha.
If one does not take refuge in one's own Buddha, there is no place to rely on.

Now that you have awakened on your own, each of you must take refuge in the Three Jewels of your own mind, regulate your mind-nature within, and respect others externally - this is taking refuge in yourself.
Good friends!

Since you have already taken refuge in your own Three Jewels, each of you with a sincere mind, I will explain the self-nature Buddha of the one-body three-bodies for you, enabling you to clearly see the three bodies and awaken to your own nature.
Simply follow my words:ğŸ”½In your own physical body, take refuge in the pure Dharma-body Buddha.
In your own physical body, take refuge in the perfect Reward-body Buddha.
In your own physical body, take refuge in the myriad koá¹­is of nayutas of Transformation-body Buddhas.
Good friends!
The physical body is a dwelling, not to be said to be taking refuge.
The three-body Buddhas are in your own nature, which everyone in the world has;
It is because your own mind is deluded that you do not see your inner nature.
Seeking the three-body TathÄgatas externally, you do not see that within your own body there are the three-body Buddhas.
Listen to me explaining, so that you can see the three-body Buddha within your own nature.
This three-body Buddha arises from your own nature and is not obtained from outside.
What is the pure Dharma-body Buddha?
The nature of human beings is originally pure, and myriad dharmas arise from one's own nature.
Thinking of all evil things gives rise to evil conduct;
thinking of all good things gives rise to good conduct.
Such dharmas are in one's own nature, like the sky being always clear, the sun and moon always bright, but covered by floating clouds, above being bright and below being dark.
Suddenly encountering a wind that blows away the clouds, above and below are both bright, and myriad forms appear.
The nature of human beings is always floating and wandering, like those sky clouds.
Good friends!
Wisdom is like the sun, and discernment is like the moon, with wisdom and discernment always bright.
Outside, attached to objects, covered by the floating clouds of false thoughts, one's own nature cannot be clearly seen.

If one encounters a good and wise advisor and hears the true and proper Dharma, one can remove delusion and confusion by oneself, and the inside and outside become clear and penetrating. In one's own nature, myriad dharmas all manifest.
A person who sees the nature is also like this.
This is called the pure Dharma body Buddha.
Good and wise advisor!
Taking refuge in one's own mind and one's own nature is taking refuge in the true Buddha.

Those who take refuge by themselves remove the unwholesome mind, jealous mind, flattering mind, egotistical mind, deceitful mind, arrogant mind, conceited mind, wrong view mind, and proud mind in their own nature, as well as all unwholesome actions at all times. They always see their own faults and do not speak of others' good and bad. This is taking refuge by oneself.
One should always lower one's mind and universally practice respectfulness. This is seeing the nature and penetrating through, without any further obstruction. This is taking refuge by oneself.
What is called the perfect reward body?
It is like how one lamp can remove a thousand years of darkness, and one wisdom can extinguish myriad years of foolishness.
Do not think of what has already passed, for it cannot be obtained;
Always think of the future, and in every thought be perfectly clear, and you will see your own nature.
Although good and evil differ, the fundamental nature is non-dual. The non-dual nature is called the true nature.

Within the true nature, one is not tainted by good or evil. This is called the perfect reward body Buddha.ğŸ”½If one gives rise to a single thought of evil in one's nature, it destroys the causes of goodness for myriad eons;
If one gives rise to a single thought of good in one's nature, it causes the ending of countless evils.
Until one attains supreme enlightenment, one sees in every thought, and does not lose one's original thought. This is called the reward body.
What is meant by the myriad koá¹­is of transformation bodies?
If one does not think of the myriad dharmas, their nature is originally like empty space. A single thought of conceptualization is called transformation.
Conceptualizing evil things transforms into hell;
Conceptualizing good things transforms into heaven.
Poisonous harm transforms into dragons and snakes, compassion transforms into bodhisattvas, wisdom transforms into the upper realms, and ignorance transforms into the lower realms.
The transformations of one's own nature are very numerous, but deluded people cannot realize it. Moment by moment, they give rise to evil and always walk the evil path.
Turning a single thought of goodness, wisdom is born. This is called the transformation body Buddha of one's own nature.
Good spiritual friend!
The Dharma body is originally endowed. Seeing one's own nature moment by moment is the reward body Buddha.
Thinking from the reward body is the transformation body Buddha.
Self-realization, self-cultivation, and the merits of one's own nature are the true refuge.
Skin and flesh are the physical body, and the physical body is the dwelling, but it is not said to be the refuge.
But if one realizes the three bodies of one's own nature, one recognizes the Buddha of one's own nature.
I have a verse on formlessness. If you can uphold it, it will cause your accumulated deluded offenses to be instantly extinguished.
The verse says:
Deluded people cultivate merit but not the Way, only saying that cultivating merit is the Way,
Generosity and offerings have boundless merit, but in the mind, they originally create three kinds of evil.
Intending to use cultivated merit to extinguish offenses, in the next life, one obtains merit but offenses remain.
Only eliminate the conditions for offenses in the mind, which is called true repentance within one's own nature.
Suddenly realizing the true repentance of the Great Vehicle, removing evil and practicing the correct is without offense.
Cultivating the Way, always contemplate one's own nature, and one is of the same category as the Buddhas.
Our ancestor only transmits this sudden Dharma, universally wishing to see the nature and be of the same essence,
If one wishes to seek the Dharma body in the future, wash it in the mind, apart from the characteristics of dharmas.
Strive to see it yourself, do not be lax, after death, suddenly cut off and rest for a lifetime.
If one realizes the Great Vehicle and sees the nature, respectfully join palms and sincerely seek. The master said:
Good friends!
You must all recite this and practice according to it, and you will see your nature right where you are.
Even if you go a thousand miles away, you will always be by my side.
If you do not awaken to this right now, then even if you are face to face with me, you will be a thousand miles away. Why bother coming from afar?
Treasure it!
Go well!
The entire assembly, having heard the Dharma, all opened up and awakened, joyfully accepting and practicing it.

If I were to explain in detail, it would not end even in an eon.

Seng Fadai, a person from Hongzhou, left home at the age of seven and always recited the Lotus Sutra.

The master said:

But now you are burdened with this practice and do not know your faults at all.
Listen to my verse:

If there is self, then sin arises; if there is no self, then merit is incomparable.
The master said again:

He replied:ğŸ”½Fa-da.

Since you have a connection now, I will speak for you,

When Fa-da heard the verse, he repented and apologized, saying:

Your disciple recites the Lotus Sutra, but I do not understand the meaning of the sutra, and my mind always has doubts.
The master's wisdom is vast, please briefly explain the meaning of the sutra.
The master said:
Fa-da!

The sutra is originally without doubt, it is your own mind that doubts.
What do you take as the essence of this sutra?
Fa-da said:
This student's faculties are dull, I have always just recited the text, how could I know the essence?
The master said:

Fa-da then recited the sutra in a loud voice, up to the Parable Chapter, the master said:
Stop!
This sutra originally takes the cause and conditions for appearing in the world as its essence, even if it speaks of many kinds of parables, it does not go beyond this.
What are the causes and conditions?
The sutra says:
'The buddhas, the world-honored ones, appear in the world for only one great cause and condition.
The one great matter is the Buddha's knowledge and insight.
Worldly people are externally confused by attachment to appearances and internally confused by attachment to emptiness;
If one can be free from appearances within appearances and free from emptiness within emptiness, then this is being neither externally nor internally confused.
If one awakens to this Dharma, with a single thought one's mind opens, and this is called opening the Buddha's knowledge and insight.
Buddha is still enlightenment.

It is divided into four approaches: opening the knowledge and insight of enlightenment, revealing the knowledge and insight of enlightenment, awakening to the knowledge and insight of enlightenment, and entering the knowledge and insight of enlightenment.
If one hears the revelation and is able to awaken and enter, then the knowledge and insight of enlightenment, which is the original true nature, will appear.
You must not misunderstand the meaning of the sutra and see others say:
Opening, revealing, awakening, and entering are the Buddha's own knowledge and insight.
We have no share in this.
If you understand it in this way, you are slandering the sutra and denigrating the Buddha.
Since they are already Buddhas, they already possess knowledge and insight, so what need is there to open them further?
You should now have faith that the one who knows and sees the Buddha is none other than your own mind.

It is only because all sentient beings cover their own light, crave for the dust and sense objects, are disturbed by external conditions and internal afflictions, and willingly submit to being driven around.
It then troubles the World-Honored One to arise from samÄdhi and, with various kinds of bitter admonitions, encourages them to rest and not seek externally, as there is no difference from the Buddha.
Therefore, it is said:
Open the Buddha's knowledge and insight.
I also encourage all people to always open the Buddha's knowledge and insight in their own minds.

The minds of worldly people are crooked, foolish, and deluded in creating offenses. Their mouths are good while their hearts are evil, greedy, hateful, jealous, deceitful, arrogant, encroaching upon others, harming beings, and opening the knowledge and insight of sentient beings themselves.
If one is able to be upright in mind and always give rise to wisdom, contemplate and illuminate one's own mind, cease evil and do good, this is opening the Buddha's knowledge and insight oneself.
You should think of opening the Buddha's knowledge and insight at every moment, and not open the knowledge and insight of sentient beings.
Opening the Buddha's insight is transcending the world;
Opening the insight of sentient beings is the mundane world.
If you just laboriously recite and consider it your practice, how are you different from a yak loving its tail?
Dharma Protector said:
If that's so, then is it enough to understand the meaning without reciting the sutra?
The master said:
What's wrong with the sutra? How does it hinder your recitation?
It's just that delusion and enlightenment are in the person, and loss and gain depend on oneself.ğŸ”½Reciting with the mouth and practicing in the mind is turning the sutra;
Reciting with the mouth but not practicing in the mind is being turned by the sutra.
Listen to my verse:
The mind deluded, the Lotus Sutra turns; the mind enlightened, the Lotus Sutra turns.
Reciting the sutra for a long time without understanding is creating enmity with the meaning.
No thought is correct; with thought, thought becomes deviant.
Not calculating existence or non-existence, one always drives the white ox cart.
When Dajue heard the verse, he suddenly wept with emotion and was greatly enlightened. He said to the master:
Since ancient times, I have never turned the Lotus Sutra, but now I have been turned by the Lotus Sutra.
He then asked again:
The sutra says:
'The great shravakas and even the bodhisattvas exhaust their thoughts and calculations together, yet they cannot fathom the Buddha's wisdom.'
Now it tells ordinary people to simply awaken to their own minds and call it the Buddha's knowledge and vision.
If it were not for those of the highest faculties, they would inevitably doubt and slander it.
Moreover, the sutra speaks of three vehicles: the sheep, deer, and ox carts, and the white ox cart. How are they distinguished?
I wish for the master to give further instruction.
The master said:
The meaning of the sutra is clear, but you yourself are confused and turn your back on it.
As for the three vehicles being unable to fathom the Buddha's wisdom, the problem lies in their measurements.
Even if they exhaust their thoughts and calculations together, it will only become more distant.
The Buddha originally spoke for ordinary people, not for buddhas.
If you are unwilling to believe this principle, then leave the assembly.
But how could you know that you have already sat in the white ox cart, yet you still seek the three carts outside the gate?
Moreover, the sÅ«tra clearly tells you:
There is only the Buddha vehicle, there is no other vehicle, whether second or third.
Up to countless skillful means, various causes, conditions, parables, and words, all these teachings are for the sake of the one Buddha vehicle.
Why don't you understand that the three carts are provisional, for the sake of the past;
The one vehicle is real, for the sake of the present.
It only teaches you to abandon the provisional and return to the real. After returning to the real, the real also has no name.
You should know that all the precious wealth belongs to you. Because you enjoy it, you no longer have the thought of a father, nor the thought of a son, nor the thought of using it.
This is called upholding the Lotus SÅ«tra. From eon to eon, your hands never leave the scroll. From day to night, there is no time when you do not think of it.
Damo was enlightened and overjoyed. He praised in verse:
I have recited the sutras three thousand times, but at Caoxi, I let go of a single phrase.
Before I understood the meaning of transcending the world, how could I stop the madness of accumulating lives?
The vehicles of humans, devas, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas are provisionally established. In the beginning, middle, and end, the good is proclaimed.
Who would have known that within the burning house, it is originally the Dharma King?
The master said:
From now on, you can be called a monk who recites the sutras.
From then on, Damo understood the profound meaning and did not stop reciting the sutras.
Monk Zhitong, a person from Anfeng, Shouzhou.
He first read the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra.
For over a thousand times, but he did not understand the three bodies and four knowledges.
He bowed to the master and asked for an explanation of the meaning. The master said:

Not apart from the conditions of seeing and hearing, one suddenly ascends to the stage of Buddhahood.
I now explain it for you; if you believe it, you will never be confused.
Do not learn from those who run around seeking, who all day long speak of enlightenment.
Tong again said:

He further spoke a verse:
The nature of the great perfect mirror wisdom is pure, the wisdom of equality of mind is free from illness,
The seen aspect of the wondrous observing cognition is not a function, and the accomplishing cognition is the same as the perfect mirror.
The fifth, eighth, sixth, and seventh are the results and causes of transformation, but they are only used as names and have no real nature.
If one does not dwell on the place of transformation, then one eternally abides in the samÄdhi of the nÄga.
As above, the transforming consciousnesses become wisdom.

The teachings say: Transforming the first five consciousnesses into the accomplishing cognition, transforming the sixth consciousness into the wondrous observing cognition, transforming the seventh consciousness into the cognition of equality, and transforming the eighth consciousness into the great perfect mirror cognition.
Although the sixth and seventh are transformed in the cause, the fifth and eighth are transformed in the result, it is only the names that are transformed, not the substance.
Comprehending the sudden awakening of intrinsic wisdom, he presented a verse, saying:
The three bodies are originally my essence, the four wisdoms are the mind's original clarity.
The bodies and wisdoms merge without obstruction, responding to beings and adapting to their forms.
Cultivating practice is all false movement, guarding and abiding is not the true essence.
The wondrous meaning is understood through the teacher, and the defiled name is ultimately lost.
Seng Zhichang, a person from Guixi, Xinzhou, left home at a young age and was determined to seek to see the nature.
One day he visited the master, who asked:

What do you seek?
He replied:
The student recently went to Mount Bai Feng in Hongzhou to pay respects to Great Master Datong. I received the teaching on seeing the nature and becoming a buddha.
I have not yet resolved my doubts and have come from afar to pay respects. I humbly hope that the master will have compassion and point the way.
The master said:
What words and phrases did he have?
Try to bring them up. He replied:
I stayed there for three months, but did not receive any instruction.
Because I was so eager for the Dharma, one evening I entered his room alone and asked:
'What is my original mind and original nature?'
Great Master Datong said:
'Do you see the sky?'
I replied:ğŸ”½Yes, I see it.
'I see.'
He said:
'Do you see any form or appearance in the sky?'
He replied:
'The sky has no form, so how can there be any form or appearance?'
He said:
'Your fundamental nature is just like empty space, with nothing whatsoever that can be seen. This is called right seeing;
with nothing whatsoever that can be known, this is called true knowing.

Although the student heard this explanation, he still was not certain, and begged the master for further instruction.
The master said:
What that teacher said still involves seeing and knowing, so it has caused you to be uncertain.
I will now show you a verse:
Not seeing a single dharma, yet abiding in non-seeing, is like floating clouds covering the sun,
Not knowing the one dharma, guarding emptiness and knowing, is like the great void giving rise to lightning.
This knowing and seeing suddenly arises, mistakenly grasping without ever understanding the skillful means,
You should at once realize it is not so, and your own spiritual light will always manifest.
Having heard this verse, Zhiyi's mind suddenly opened up.
He then composed a verse, saying:
Pointlessly giving rise to knowing and seeing, grasping at characteristics to seek bodhi,
With thoughts dwelling on a single moment of enlightenment, how can one transcend the delusion of the past?
The essence of the source of self-nature is aware, yet following illumination, it mistakenly flows,
Not entering the patriarch's room, one is confused and goes to both extremes.
One day, Zhiyi asked the master, saying:

I have not yet understood, please instruct me.
The master said:
Observe your own original mind, do not grasp at external phenomena.

Seeing, hearing, reciting is the Lesser Vehicle;
Understanding the Dharma and comprehending the meaning is the Middle Vehicle;
Relying on the Dharma to practice is the Great Vehicle;
Comprehending all dharmas, possessing all dharmas, being unstained by anything, free from all characteristics of dharmas, attaining nothing, is called the Supreme Vehicle.
Vehicle means the meaning of practice, not arguing with the mouth.
You should cultivate yourself, do not ask me.
At all times, the nature is self-so.
He always bowed in respect and served until the end of the master's life.
Seng Zhidao, from Nanhai, Guangzhou.
He asked for instruction, saying:
Since I left home, I have read the Nirvana Sutra for more than ten years, but I still do not understand the great meaning. I wish the Venerable Master would give me guidance.
The master said:
Where do you not understand?
He said:
All conditioned things are impermanent, they are dharmas of arising and ceasing;
When birth and cessation cease, quiescent extinction is bliss.
I have doubts about this.
The master said:
How do you doubt it?
He said:
All sentient beings have two bodies, namely the physical body and the Dharma body.
The physical body is impermanent, subject to birth and cessation;
The Dharma body is permanent, without cognition or awareness.
The sutra says:
'When birth and cessation cease, quiescent extinction is bliss.' I do not know which body is quiescent and extinct,
And which body experiences bliss?
If it is the physical body, when the physical body perishes, the four elements disperse, and it is entirely suffering. Suffering cannot be called bliss.
If the Dharma body is quiescent and extinct, it is the same as grass, trees, tiles, and stones. Who would experience bliss?

Moreover, the nature of dharmas is the essence of birth and cessation, and the five aggregates are the function of birth and cessation. One essence and five functions, birth and cessation are constant.
When arising, it arises from the essence and gives rise to function. When ceasing, it subsumes function and returns to the essence.
If you allow rebirth, then the category of sentient beings will be uninterrupted and undestroyed;
If you do not allow rebirth, then they will forever return to quiescent extinction, the same as insentient things.
In this way, all dharmas will be subdued by nirvana and will not be allowed to arise, so what joy is there?
The master said:
You are a disciple of ÅšÄkyamuni, yet you practice the heretical views of annihilationism and eternalism, and discuss the supreme vehicle?
According to what you say, there is a dharmakÄya separate from the physical body, seeking quiescent extinction apart from arising and ceasing.
Moreover, you posit nirvana as permanent bliss, saying there is a body to experience and enjoy it.
This is clinging to and begrudging birth and death, indulging in worldly pleasures.

You should now know that the Buddha, for all deluded people who take the combination of the five aggregates as their self-nature, discriminates all dharmas as external dust-like characteristics, likes to be born and dislikes death, with thoughts and thoughts passing away, not knowing they are illusory and false, vainly undergoing cyclic existence.
Taking the constant bliss of nirvana as suffering, they pursue it all day long.
The Buddha, out of compassion for them, shows the true bliss of nirvana.
In a moment, there is no arising, in a moment there is no ceasing, and there is no arising and ceasing to be extinguished. This is the manifestation of quiescent extinction.
When it is manifested, there is no measure of manifestation, and it is called constant bliss.
This bliss has no one who experiences it, and no one who does not experience it. How can there be the name of one essence and five functions?
How much less can it be said that nirvana suppresses all dharmas and makes them never arise again?
This is slandering the Buddha and defaming the Dharma.
Listen to my verse:
The unsurpassed great nirvana, perfect and bright, constantly illuminating,
