I will now teach you how to expound the Dharma without losing the fundamental teaching:
First, you must present the three categories of Dharma gates, which are in motion and use thirty-six pairs, and appear and disappear, immediately leaving both sides.
When expounding all dharmas, do not leave one's own nature.
Suddenly, if someone asks you about the Dharma, all your words will be dualistic, and you will be using the Dharma to respond to them, coming and going in mutual dependence.
Ultimately, the two Dharmas will be completely eliminated, and there will be no place to go.
The three categories of Dharma gates are the aggregates, elements, and sense bases.
The aggregates are the five aggregates - form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.
The sense bases are the twelve sense bases, the external six sense objects - form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas;
and the internal six sense organs - eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
The elements are the eighteen elements, the six sense objects, the six sense organs, and the six consciousnesses.
The inherent nature that can contain myriad dharmas is called the store consciousness.
If thoughts arise, it is the evolving consciousness.
It produces the six consciousnesses, emerges through the six sense organs, and perceives the six sense objects.
In this way, the eighteen elements all arise from inherent nature.
If inherent nature is wrong, it gives rise to the eighteen kinds of wrongness;
If the nature is correct, then eighteen correct [actions] arise.
If the evil use is the use of sentient beings, then the good use is the use of Buddhas.
What does the use depend on?
It depends on the existence of the nature, and the external objects of the Abhidharma.
There are five pairs without sentience:
Heaven and earth are a pair, the sun and moon are a pair, light and darkness are a pair, yin and yang are a pair, water and fire are a pair;
these are the five pairs.
The Dharma characteristics and language have twelve pairs:

Words and Dharma are a pair, existence and non-existence are a pair, form and no-form are a pair, characteristics and no-characteristics are a pair, contaminated and uncontaminated are a pair, form and emptiness are a pair, movement and stillness are a pair, clear and turbid are a pair, ordinary and sage are a pair, monk and layperson are a pair, old and young are a pair, large and small are a pair;
these are the twelve pairs.
The nature gives rise to nineteen pairs of uses:

Long and short are opposites, crooked and straight are opposites, delusion and wisdom are opposites, foolish and wise are opposites, chaos and concentration are opposites, kindness and poison are opposites, precepts and non-precepts are opposites, upright and crooked are opposites, true and false are opposites, dangerous and level are opposites, afflictions and bodhi are opposites, permanence and impermanence are opposites, compassion and harm are opposites, joy and anger are opposites, abandonment and stinginess are opposites, progress and retreat are opposites, birth and death are opposites, the Dharma body and the physical body are opposites, the transformation body and the reward body are opposites;
these are the nineteen pairs.
The master said:
These thirty-six pairs of dharmas, if understood and used, are the path that penetrates all sutras. Entering and exiting is being free from the two extremes.
The self-nature moves and functions, and when speaking with others, externally it is free from characteristics and characteristics, internally it is free from emptiness and emptiness.
If one is completely attached to characteristics, then one will grow in wrong views;
if one completely grasps emptiness, then one will grow in ignorance.
Those who cling to emptiness slander the sutras, saying that they are useless.
Since they say that words are useless, people should not speak.
These very words are the characteristics of words.
They also say:
Directly speaking, words are not established.
These two words not established are also words.
Seeing what others say, they immediately slander others, saying they cling to words.
You should know that self-delusion is still possible, but to slander the Buddha's sutras again,
Do not slander the sutras, the karmic hindrances are countless.
If one clings to external characteristics and seeks truth through practices,
Or widely establishes Dharma assemblies, speaking of the faults of existence and non-existence,
Such a person will not be able to see the nature for many kalpas.
Just listen and practice according to the Dharma, and do not obstruct the nature of the Way by not thinking of anything.
If one listens to the teachings but does not practice, it causes one to give rise to deviant thoughts.
But rely on practicing the Dharma, and give the Dharma of non-abiding characteristics.
If you understand, then rely on this to speak, rely on this to use, rely on this to practice, rely on this to act, and you will not lose the fundamental teaching.

If someone asks you about the meaning, if they ask about existence with non-existence, answer with existence. If they ask about non-existence with existence, answer with non-existence. If they ask about the ordinary with the sagely, answer with the ordinary. If they ask about the sagely with the ordinary, answer with the sagely.
The two paths mutually cause each other, giving rise to the meaning of the middle way.
For every question and answer, the rest of the questions should be answered based on this, and then the principle will not be lost.
Suppose someone asks:
What is called darkness?
The answer is:
Light is the cause, darkness is the condition. When light disappears, it becomes dark.
Using light to manifest darkness, using darkness to manifest light, coming and going mutually causing each other, forming the meaning of the middle way.
The rest of the questions are all like this.
When you transmit the Dharma in the future, rely on this to teach each other, and do not lose the fundamental teaching.

The master, in the first year of Taiji, the Renzi year, the seventh month of Yanhe this year, the fifth month was changed to Yanhe, the eighth month Xuanzong ascended the throne and changed the era name to Xiantian, the following year he changed it to Kaiyuan.

The other version says Xiantian is incorrect. He ordered his disciples to go to Guoneng Temple in Xinzhou to build a stupa, and also ordered them to hurry the construction, and it was completed at the end of the following summer.
On the first day of the seventh month, he gathered the assembly and said:
I will leave the world in the eighth month.
If you have doubts, you should ask me early, so that I can resolve your doubts and clear away your confusion.
After I am gone, there will be no one to teach you.
Fahai and the others, upon hearing this, all wept.
Only Shenhui, his expression unchanged, did not weep.
The master said:
Shenhui's young disciple has attained the ability to remain unmoved by praise or blame, and unaffected by sorrow or joy;
The others have not attained this.
What path have you been cultivating in the mountains for several years?
You are now weeping, for whom do you grieve?
If you grieve that I do not know where I am going, I myself know where I am going.
If I did not know where I am going, I would never inform you in advance.
Your weeping is because you do not know where I am going;
if you knew where I am going, you would not weep.

The nature of dharmas is originally without birth, cessation, going, or coming. All of you sit down, I will speak a verse for you, called the Verse on the Movement and Stillness of the True and False.
You should recite this verse, its meaning is the same as mine, if you practice according to it, you will not lose the fundamental purport.
The assembly of monks bowed and requested the master to speak the verse.
The verse said:
All is without truth, not by seeing truth,
If one sees truth, this seeing is all not true.
If one can have truth for oneself, apart from falsehood, the mind is true,
One's own mind is not apart from falsehood, without truth, where is truth?
Sentient beings are liberated from movement, insentient beings are immovable,
If one cultivates the practice of immovability, it is the same as the immovability of insentient beings.
If one seeks true immovability, there is immovability above movement,
Immovability is immovability, insentient beings have no Buddha-nature.
One who can skillfully discriminate characteristics, the ultimate truth is immovable,
Merely giving rise to such a view is the function of suchness.
I inform all practitioners to exert effort and apply their minds,
Do not within the gate of the Great Vehicle, revert to grasping the wisdom of birth and death.
If one says it accords with the lower, then discuss the meaning of the Buddha together;
If it is truly not in accord, join palms and bring joy.
This school is originally free from dispute, dispute then loses the intention of the Way,
Grasping the Dharma gate of inverted dispute, the intrinsic nature enters birth and death.

When the assembly heard this verse, they all bowed and understood the master's intention. Each one focused their mind and practiced according to the Dharma, no longer daring to argue. They knew that the great master would not remain in the world for long.
The senior monk Fazhao bowed twice and asked:
After the master's nirvana, to whom should the robe and Dharma be entrusted?
The master said:
At the Great Brahma Temple, I have expounded the Dharma up to now. The recorded teachings are circulating, called the 'Dharma Jewel Altar Sutra.'
You all should protect it and transmit it to each other.
Liberate all beings. Merely rely on this teaching, and it is called the true Dharma.
Now, I have expounded the Dharma for you, but I will not entrust the robe to you.
It is because your faculties of faith are pure and mature, and you are free from doubt. You are capable of great matters.
However, according to the meaning of the verse for entrusting the Dharma by the ancestral master Bodhidharma, the robe should not be transmitted.
The verse says:
I originally came to this land to transmit the Dharma and save deluded beings.
One flower opens into five petals, and the fruit forms naturally.
The master continued:
All good and virtuous friends!
Each of you should listen with a pure mind as I expound the Dharma.
If you wish to accomplish the wisdom of all modes, you must attain the samÄdhi of one characteristic and the samÄdhi of one practice.

If you do not dwell in characteristics in any situation, do not give rise to aversion or attachment towards those characteristics, do not engage in grasping or rejecting, and do not think of matters of benefit, accomplishment, or destruction, but remain at ease, tranquil, empty, and pure, this is called the samÄdhi of one characteristic.

If in all situations, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, you maintain a pure and upright mind, do not leave the place of practice, and truly perfect the pure land, this is called the samÄdhi of one practice.
If a person possesses these two samÄdhis, it is like the earth containing seeds, nurturing and ripening them.
The samÄdhi of one characteristic and the samÄdhi of one practice are also like this.
I now expound the Dharma, like timely rain, universally moistening the great earth.
Your Buddha-nature is like various seeds, encountering this moistening, all able to sprout.
Those who uphold my meaning will certainly attain Bodhi.
Those who follow my practice will definitely realize the wondrous fruit.
Listen to my verse:
The mind-ground contains all seeds, universally rained upon, all sprouting.
Suddenly realizing the mind's nature, the Bodhi fruit is naturally accomplished.
After the master spoke the verse, he said:
The Dharma is non-dual, and the mind is also thus.
The Way is pure and also devoid of various characteristics. You should all refrain from contemplating stillness and emptiness in your mind.
This mind is originally pure, with nothing to accept or reject.
Each of you should strive diligently, and go well according to conditions.
At that time, the assembly bowed and withdrew.
On the eighth day of the seventh month, the Great Master suddenly said to his disciples:
I wish to return to Xinzhou. You should quickly prepare the boat.
The great assembly pleaded with him to stay, but he was very firm.
The master said:
Even though the Buddhas appear, they still demonstrate nirvana.
What comes must go, and the principle is also always so.
This body of mine must return to where it came from.
The assembly said:
Where will the master go from here? Can you come back early or late?
The master said:
When the leaves fall, they return to the roots. When coming, there are no words.
They also asked:
To whom will the treasury of the true Dharma eye be transmitted?
The master said:
One with the Way can attain it, and one without mind can penetrate it.
They also asked:
Will there be difficulties later?
The master said:
Five or six years after my extinction, someone will come to take my head. Listen to my prediction:
'Nourish one's relatives on the head, and eat in the mouth. Encountering a full difficulty, Yang Liu will become an official.'
It also says:
In seventy years after I leave, two bodhisattvas will come from the east, one a monk and one a layperson.
They will simultaneously promote the teachings and establish my school, building monasteries and flourishing the Dharma lineage.
He asked:
I do not yet know how many generations have passed since the ancient Buddhas and Patriarchs manifested and transmitted the teachings.
Please bestow an explanation.
The master said:
The ancient Buddhas who appeared in the world are innumerable and incalculable.

On the third day of the eighth month in the second year of the Xiantian era (10th day of the 12th month of the same year, the reign title was changed to Kaiyuan), the Great Master said to the assembly of disciples after the feast at the Guoneng Temple:
You should all sit in your places. I will take leave of you.
Fahai said:
Venerable!
What teachings should be left behind to allow deluded people of later generations to see their Buddha-nature?
The master said:
Listen carefully!
If people of later generations recognize sentient beings as the Buddha-nature,
if they do not recognize sentient beings, it will be difficult to encounter the Buddha for ten thousand kalpas.
I now teach you.
Recognize sentient beings in your own mind and see the Buddha-nature in your own mind.
If you wish to see the Buddha, just recognize sentient beings.
It is because sentient beings are deluded about the Buddha, not because the Buddha is deluded about sentient beings.
If your own nature is enlightened, sentient beings are the Buddha;
if your own nature is deluded, the Buddha is a sentient being.ğŸ”½If your own nature is equal, sentient beings are the Buddha;
if your own nature is crooked, the Buddha is a sentient being.
If your mind is crooked, the Buddha is within sentient beings;
if your thoughts are upright,
sentient beings become Buddhas.
The Buddha is within my own mind, and my own Buddha is the true Buddha.
If you do not have the Buddha-mind yourself, where can you seek the true Buddha?
Your own mind is the Buddha, do not doubt it any further.
There is not a single external thing that can establish anything, all are the myriad kinds of dharmas born from the fundamental mind.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says:
When the mind arises, the myriad dharmas arise; when the mind ceases, the myriad dharmas cease.
I now leave a verse to part from you all, called the Verse on the True Buddha of Self-Nature.
People of later generations who understand the meaning of this verse will see their fundamental mind themselves and attain Buddhahood themselves.
The verse says:
True suchness, self-nature is the true Buddha; evil views and the three poisons are the demon king.
When deluded, the demon resides in the house; when seeing correctly, the Buddha is in the hall.ğŸ”½Evil views and the three poisons born within nature
Are the demon king coming to reside in the house;ğŸ”½Correct views naturally remove the mind of the three poisons,
The demon transforms into the Buddha, truly without falsehood.
Dharma body, reward body, and transformation body, the three bodies are originally one body,
If one can see it in one's nature, it is the cause of attaining Buddhahood.
Originally born from the transformation body into pure nature, pure nature always abides in the transformation body,
Nature causes the transformation body to practice the right path, in the future it will be perfect and truly inexhaustible.
The nature of desire is originally the cause of pure nature, eliminating desire is the body of pure nature,
In nature, each is apart from the five desires, seeing nature in an instant is true.
If one encounters the sudden teaching in this life, suddenly awakening to one's own nature and seeing the World-Honored One,
If one wishes to practice and seek to become a Buddha, not knowing where to seek truth?
If one can see truth in one's own mind, having truth is the cause of becoming a Buddha,
Not seeing one's own nature and seeking Buddha outside, giving rise to thoughts is entirely a deluded person.
The sudden teaching method has now been left behind, to save and deliver the people of the world, you must cultivate it yourself.
I tell you, those who will study the Way in the future, do not make this view, which is greatly deluded.
After the master spoke the verse, he said:
You all should stay well.
After my nirvana, do not act with worldly emotions, crying tears of grief, receiving condolences, and wearing mourning clothes. You are not my disciples, nor is it the true Dharma.

But recognize your own original mind, see your own original nature, which is without movement, without stillness, without birth, without cessation, without going, without coming, without rightness, without wrongness, without dwelling, without departing.
I fear that your minds are confused and you will not understand my meaning. Now I entrust it to you again, to enable you to see your nature.
After my nirvana, rely on this practice, as if I were still here;
If you go against my teachings, even if I were still in the world, it would be of no benefit.
He further spoke a verse, saying:
Carelessly not creating evil,ğŸ”½Quietly cutting off seeing and hearing,
Carefree mind without attachment.
After the master spoke the verse, he sat upright until the third watch, and suddenly said to his disciples:
I am leaving!
He then passed away.
At that time, strange fragrance filled the room, a white rainbow touched the ground, the trees turned white, and the birds and beasts cried mournfully.

In the eleventh month, the officials of the three prefectures of Guang, Shao, and Xin, as well as the disciples, both monastic and lay, vied to welcome the true body, unable to decide where it should go.
They then burned incense and prayed, saying:
Where the incense smoke points, that is where the master should return.
At that time, the incense smoke went straight to Caoxi.
On the thirteenth day of the eleventh month, they moved the shrine and the robe and alms bowl that were passed down and returned.

The following year, in the seventh month, the coffin was taken out. Disciple Fang Bian applied fragrant mud to it. The disciple Ni Nian took the record of the head and still used iron leaves and lacquer cloth to firmly protect the master's neck and place it in the stupa.
Suddenly, white light appeared inside the stupa, going straight up to the sky, and only dispersed after three days.
Shaozhou reported it to the court, and an imperial decree was issued to establish a stele to record the master's way of practice.

The master was seventy-six years old. At twenty-four, he received the robe of transmission. At thirty-nine, he shaved his head. He spoke the Dharma and benefited sentient beings for thirty-seven years. He had forty-three Dharma heirs. Those who attained the Way and transcended the ordinary were countless.

The robe of transmission passed down by Bodhidharma was made of Indian cotton cloth. The central emperor bestowed a robe of grinding dust and a precious alms bowl, as well as Fang Bian's sculpted likeness of the master and his ritual implements, which were permanently enshrined in the Bao Lin Dharma site.
He left behind the Platform Sutra to manifest the fundamental principles, to flourish the Three Jewels, and to universally benefit all beings.

The Great Master's name was Huineng, his father was the Lu family, and his personal name was Xingjian. In the third year of Wude in the Tang Dynasty, he was appointed to Xinzhou.
His mother, Lady Li, first dreamed that white flowers bloomed in the courtyard, and a pair of white cranes flew together, with strange fragrance filling the room. She woke up and became pregnant.

She then purified her sincerity and observed the precepts, carrying the fetus for six years before the master was born. It was on the eighth day of the second month in the twelfth year of the Zhenguan era in the Tang Dynasty, in the zi hour.
At that time, a ray of light rose into the sky, and the fragrance of incense permeated the air.
In the early morning, two monks came to visit and said to the master's father:
The child born last night, we will name him. Above, it is Hui; below, it is Neng.
The father said:
Why is he named Huineng?
The monks said:ğŸ”½The name is not in vain.
The wise one uses the Dharma to benefit sentient beings, the capable one is able to perform Buddha's work.
After saying this, he left, and no one knew where he went.
The master did not drink his mother's milk, but at night divine beings would feed him with sweet dew.
When he was three years old, his father passed away, and he was buried beside their home.
His mother raised him with determination, and when he grew up, he sold firewood to support his mother.
At the age of twenty-four, he heard the sutras and had an awakening.

He went to Huangmei to pay respects to the Fifth Patriarch, who recognized his potential and entrusted him with the robe and Dharma, ordering him to succeed to the Patriarch's position. This was in the first year of Longshuo, the year Xinyou.

He returned south and went into hiding. In the first year of Yifeng, the year Bingzi, on the eighth day of the first month, he met with Dharma Master Yin Zong and had a discussion on the profound principles. Yin Zong understood and agreed with the master's teachings.
On the fifteenth day of this month, the fourfold assembly gathered to have the master shave his head.
On the eighth day of the second month, he gathered various virtuous monks to receive the full precepts.

Vinaya Master Zhiguang of the Western Capital was the preceptor for receiving the precepts, Vinaya Master Huijing of Suzhou was the karma master, Vinaya Master Tongying of Jingzhou was the instructor, Vinaya Master Qitian Yiduo of the Central Region was the one who explained the precepts, and Tripiá¹­aka Master Mituo of the Western Regions was the witness for the precepts.
The ordination platform was originally established by Tripiá¹­aka Master Guá¹‡abhadra of the Song Dynasty. A stele was erected, which said:
Later, there will be a bodhisattva with a physical body who will bestow the precepts here.

Moreover, in the first year of the Tianjian era of the Liang Dynasty, Tripiá¹­aka Master Zhiyao came by sea from the Western Regions. He brought a branch of the Bodhi tree from that land and planted it beside the platform. He also made a prediction, saying:

One hundred and seventy years later, there will be a bodhisattva with a physical body who will expound the supreme vehicle under this tree and liberate innumerable sentient beings. He will be the Dharma master who truly transmits the Buddha's mind seal.

The master arrived and shaved his head and received the precepts. He then revealed the meaning of the single transmission to the four assemblies, just as in the ancient prophecy. The following spring, the master took leave of the assembly and returned to Baolin. Yin Zong and over a thousand monks and laypeople saw him off as far as Caoxi.
At that time, Vinaya Master Tongying of Jingzhou was staying with the master, accompanied by several hundred students.
When the master arrived at Baolin in Caoxi, he saw that the halls and buildings were cramped and could not accommodate the assembly, so he wanted to expand them.
He then visited Chen Yaxian, a local resident, and said:
The old monk wants to ask the donor for some land for sitting cushions. Can it be done?
Yaxian said:
How wide is the master's sitting cushion?
The ancestor took out his sitting cushion to show him, and Yaxian agreed.
The Patriarch spread out his sitting mat, covering the entire area around Caoxi. The Four Heavenly Kings manifested their bodies and sat in the four directions.
Now there is Heavenly King Ridge within the temple grounds, named after this event.
The Immortal said:

I know the Venerable's Dharma power is vast and great. But my ancestors' graves are all on this land. If you build a stupa in the future, I hope you will leave it. I will give up the rest and forever make it a precious temple.
However, this land is the birthplace of the white elephant of the living dragon. It can only be leveled in the sky, not on the ground.
The temple construction behind the temple was done exactly according to his words.
The Master traveled to the scenic spots within the territory and stayed wherever he liked. Eventually, thirteen hermitages were established.
Now called Huaguo Temple, it is affiliated with the temple.

As for Baolin Temple, it was originally when the Indian Tripiá¹­aka Master Zhiyao passed through the mouth of Caoxi on his way from the South Sea, he scooped up water to drink. He found it fragrant and delicious, and thought it unusual.
He said to his disciples:
This water is no different from the water in the Western Heaven. There must be a superior place upstream, suitable for a hermitage.
Following the stream to the source, he looked around and saw the mountains and waters winding, with strange and beautiful peaks, and exclaimed:
It is just like the Bao Lin Mountain in the Western Heaven!
He then said to the residents of Cao Hou Village:

You can build a Buddhist temple on this mountain. One hundred and seventy years later, there will be an unsurpassed Dharma treasure expounded here, and those who attain the Way will be as numerous as the trees in a forest. It should be called Bao Lin.

At that time, the governor of Shaozhou, Hou Jingzhong, reported this to the emperor in detail. The emperor approved his request and granted the name Bao Lin. It then became a Buddhist palace, completed in the third year of Tianjian in the Liang dynasty.
In front of the temple hall, there was a pond where dragons often appeared, touching the oars and trees.
One day, a very large dragon appeared, with waves surging and clouds and mist shrouding the area, and the disciples were all afraid.
The master scolded him, saying:
You can only manifest a large body, but you cannot manifest a small body. If you are a divine dragon, you should be able to transform and manifest large from small, and small from large.
The dragon suddenly disappeared, and in a moment reappeared with a small body leaping out of the surface of the pond. The master opened his alms bowl and tested it, saying:
You still dare not enter the old monk's alms bowl.
The dragon then swam to the front, and the master scooped it up with his bowl. The dragon could not move.
The master held the bowl in the hall and spoke the Dharma to the dragon. The dragon then shed its bones and left.
Its bones were about seven inches long, with head, tail, horns, and feet all complete, and were passed down at the temple gate.
Later, the master filled in the pond with earth and stones. To the left in front of the current hall is an iron pagoda that marks the spot.
The waist stone of the master, inscribed with the eight characters Dragon's Radiance First Year, Recorded by Layman Lu, this stone is now at Dongchan in Huangmei.
Moreover, Wang Wei, the right vice-president of the Tang dynasty, wrote the Record of the Patriarchs for Chan Master Shenhui, saying:
The master mingled with the laborers for sixteen years. When Yinzong lectured on the sutras, he shaved his head for him.
Furthermore, Liu Zongyuan, the prefect, wrote the stele inscription for the posthumous title of the Patriarch, saying:
The master received the precepts and secluded himself on the South Sea for sixteen years.
Judging that it was the right time to practice, he then stayed at Caoxi to be a teacher for people.
Moreover, Zhang Shangying, the chancellor, wrote the Record of the Fifth Patriarch, saying:
The Fifth Patriarch spread the teachings at Dongchan Temple east of Huangmei County, which was convenient for his mother.
In the first year of Longshuo, after entrusting the robe and Dharma to the Sixth Patriarch, he dispersed the assembly and entered the eastern mountains to build a hut.
There was a resident named Pingshou who donated the mountain to the master as a place for practicing the Way.
Based on this, it is known that the master transmitted and received the robe and Dharma of the Fifth Patriarch at Huangmei in the year of Xinyou, the first year of Longshuo.
He arrived at the age of sixteen, and the master only then shaved his head at Faxing.
Other sources say he arrived at Huangmei during the Xianheng period, which is probably not correct.
The Historical Relics of Venerating the Past by Emperors of Successive Dynasties, Tang Emperor Xianzong posthumously named the Great Master as Chan Master Dajian.
Song Emperor Taizong posthumously named him Chan Master Dajian Zhenkong, and ordered the new stupa to be named Taiping Xingguo Stupa.
Song Emperor Renzong, in the tenth year of Tiansheng, welcomed the master's remains and robes into the inner palace for worship, and posthumously named him Chan Master Dajian Zhenkong Pujue.
Song Emperor Shenzong posthumously named him Chan Master Dajian Zhenkong Pujue Yuanming.
It is fully seen in the stele inscription by Yan Yuanxian.

Stele for the Posthumous Title of Chan Master Dajian, Stele for the Posthumous Title of Chan Master Dajian, written by Liu Zongyuan. The Prefect of Fufeng, Lian Wen, was exiled to the south of the Lingnan region for three years. He memorialized the emperor, saying that the Sixth Patriarch of Buddhism had not yet been given a title.
The emperor decreed to posthumously title him Chan Master Dajian, and his stupa was named Lingzhao Stupa.

On the thirteenth day of the tenth month of the tenth year of the Yuanhe era, a document from the Ministry of Rites arrived at the prefectural office. The prefect ordered the officials of the ministry and the officials of the Ministry of Personnel of the prefecture to announce it at the temple.
The banners, canopies, bells, and drums filled the mountains and valleys, and ten thousand people gathered, as if hearing of ghosts and spirits.
At that time, there were more than a thousand students, all of whom were overjoyed and inspired, as if the master had been reborn;
They were also moved to tears and longed for him, as if the master had just passed away.
He then said:
Since the beginning of life, people have enjoyed fighting, robbing, and killing each other, losing their original reality, becoming crooked and deviant, unable to return to the beginning.
Confucius had no great position, and after his death, the world was held by his remaining words. Yang, Mo, and Huang Lao became more mixed, and their techniques split.
And the teachings of our Buddha came out later, promoting detachment and returning to the source, which is called being born calm.
The Liang clan liked to create activities, and they criticized Bodhidharma, and the empty techniques became more apparent.
After six transmissions, it reached Dajian.
Dajian first followed him in enduring hard work and serving him, listening to his words alone. His words were rare, but he investigated them.
The master was moved and finally received the complete transmission.
He hid in the South Seas, and no one heard of him for another sixteen years.
Judging that he could practice, he then lived at Caoxi and became a teacher for people.
When students gathered, there were always several thousand people.
His way takes non-action as existence, takes emptiness as reality, and takes vastness and non-dissipation as the return.
In teaching people, he starts with inherent goodness and ends with inherent goodness, not needing to weed or hoe, but returning to their calmness.
The Empress Dowager Zetian heard his name and sent an envoy to invite him again, but he was unable to come. She took his words as her mind's method.
His teachings are all contained in the text.
Now spread throughout the world, all Chan teachings are based on Caoxi.
One hundred and sixty years after the Great Mirror passed away, all those who governed the Guang region and became famous could not proclaim his title.
Now, for the first time, he has informed the emperor and received a great posthumous title.
Assisting our Way, how can there be no words?

When you first entered the court, you used Confucianism to heavily punish Qianzhou and protect Annan. From the great barbarians of the sea, west of Lian Shendu, floating ships listened to your orders, all receiving your virtue, accepting the flag and halberd, coming to govern the South China Sea, vassal states like a forest, not killing, not angry, people feared without nightmares, truly illuminating with benevolence, the Great Mirror is not as bright as you, it is fitting for his disciples to be old.
So he changed the stone under the eaves, causing them to come and express their gratitude.
The text says:
Dharma transmission, dry and dry, transmitting the Buddha's mind, the sixth receiving the transmission, the great mirror is present.
Toiling diligently in silence, finally imbibing the profound, embracing the vessel of faith, walking in the darkness of the ocean.
His way was applied, at the Cao of the creek, shaggy and mixed, not leveling its loftiness.
The transmission is announced everywhere, only praising the way, born with a good nature, present in things and complete.
The wild current rushes, thus myriad its course, not thinking increases confusion, not awakening increases error.
By the teacher's inner reflection, all attain the original, not planting in the roots, not weeding the seedlings.
In the middle, one externally melts, having purity and brilliance, present in the central imperial clan, inviting words in the court.
Silently supporting the king's way, enabling people to roam freely, exceeding one hundred and six years, the posthumous title is not recorded.
By the Duke of Fufeng, announcing to the present Son of Heaven, the Minister of Education again greatly practices, thus composing the eulogy in the south.
When the Dharma arose again, its followers were tens of millions, all mourning together and rejoicing in unison.
Only the master's transformative influence reached as far as the public of Fufeng, all bearing the Son of Heaven.
The Son of Heaven's auspicious decree, appreciating the public's virtuous beauty, overflowing to the seas and barbarians, the Buddha's robe is viewed like this.
The master transmits benevolence, the public governs with benevolence, paying homage to the Buddha's robe, the eternal lineage continues unabated.

Stele of Chan Master Dajian, Stele of Chan Master Dajian and Inscription on the Buddha's Robe, both written by Liu Yuxi. On a certain day in the tenth year of Yuanhe, an imperial edict posthumously praised Neng of Caoxi, the sixth ancestor, and bestowed the posthumous name Dajian.

It was truly the governor of Guangzhou, Ma Zong, who reported it in a memorial. From this, he approved his report. Honoring the Way to respect the name, returning to goodness together, goodness does not exclude different teachings.
The praise in one word, the Chinese and barbarians are harmonious, because they have attained their place.
Mr. Ma respectfully began the matter and was careful, intending to leave it for later generations, and finally consulted with the literary hero.
Now, the Prefect of Liu Prefecture, Liu of Hedong, has erected a previous stele. Three years later, a monk named Daolin, leading his disciples, came from Caoxi and said:
I wish to establish a second stele, as a record for the students.
Since the passing of the Tathagata, in the middle five hundred years, Ma Teng and Zhu Falan brought the sutras to China, and people first heard his words, like seeing a glimmer in deep darkness.
In the later five hundred years, Bodhidharma brought the Dharma to China, and people first transmitted his mind, like seeing the bright sun at dawn.
From Bodhidharma, it was transmitted to the Great Mirror, like a string of intention pearls, with a sequence but no sameness or difference.
Those who speak of the true school in the world are called the sudden gate.
At first, Bodhidharma came with the Buddha's robe, and transmitted the Dharma to make it a true seal.
By the time of the Great Mirror, it was put aside and not transmitted. Could it be that this is a fish trap?
Or a straw dog?
How can I not know the reason for this?
I cannot understand it.
According to the record, Dajian was born in Xinzhou, left home at thirty, and passed away at forty-seven. He was posthumously titled after one hundred and six years.
He first came to Dongshan in Qi and received the prediction from the fifth teacher.
The middle emperor sent a noble person to summon him twice, but he did not obey the imperial decree.
The emperor only respected his words and carried them out.
The inscription says:
The birth of the supreme person has no kind. Those who are the same as others have form. Those who surpass others have wisdom.
In the south, a prodigy was born, with a father of dryness and a mother of earth, unique in the primordial energy.
With one word, he suddenly awakened, not treading on the first stage. The five teachers succeeded each other, bestowing upon him the precious vessel.
Sitting in meditation at Caoxi, the world called it the Southern School. The students came from afar, like water flowing east.
Drinking the wonderful medicine, curing their dumbness and deafness, the imperial edict cannot reach them, allowing them to be the heroes of the Dharma.
Far from the Buddha's sun, the myriad words accumulate in the billions, clinging to emptiness and existence, each running in their own realm.
I establish the true fishing net, hoisting it in the southern kingdom, without cultivation yet cultivating, without attainment yet attaining.
Able to make the learners return to their heavenly consciousness, like the black and confused one, looking up at the extreme of the dipper.
Attaining it naturally, in the end it cannot be transmitted, orally transmitted and handed down, then obstructed by existence.
Leaving the robe in the empty hall, the one who obtains it is bestowed by heaven.

Inscription on the Buddha's Robe, with Introduction I have already composed the second stele for Senglin at Caoxi, and I also think about how to clarify the meaning of the Sixth Patriarch's placing the robe and not transmitting it, and I write the Inscription on the Buddha's Robe.
It says:
Not practicing the Buddha's words, yet contending over the Buddha's robe, suddenly valuing the distant and belittling the near, this is the constant sentiment of ancient and modern times.
When Master Zeng died, there was not even a li of land without him. After his dream burial, his way was practiced for a thousand years.
In the past, there was Liang, like an elephant gone mad. Bodhidharma came to save the world, becoming a medicine king.
Since words did not cure it, he moved with things. Like holding a talisman, he went to the border.
The people did not know the official, but looked up to the carriage in awe. The people did not know the Buddha, but considered obtaining the robe as precious.
The dyed robe, the way is not in this. Relying on it to believe in the way, this is why it is considered a treasure.
Before the Sixth Patriarch was revealed, his appearance was subtle. After returning to the wilderness, the customs were ignorant and vulgar.
Without a vessel of faith, how could sentient beings return? This opens the convenient gate, not just transmitting the robe.
The beginning must have an end, how can the transmission not be finished? Things must return to exhaustion, how can the robe be relied upon for long?
First, knowing the end, the use is not exhausted.
My way is not decayed, what is there to the robe? Its use has already been presented, who is not a straw dog?

After the master entered the stupa, on the third day of the eighth month in the tenth year of Kaiyuan (17 August 722), in the middle of the night, they suddenly heard a sound like iron chains being dragged from inside the stupa.

The monks were startled and got up, seeing a filial son running out from inside the stupa. They then found that the master's neck had been injured. They reported the matter of the thief to the county.
County magistrate Yang Kan and prefect Liu Wuxian received the report and immediately dispatched people to capture him.
Five days later, they captured the thief in Shijiao village and sent him to Shaozhou for interrogation.
He said:
My surname is Zhang, my personal name is Jingman, and I am from Liangxian County in Ruzhou.

At Kaiyuan Temple in Hongzhou, I received twenty thousand coins from a monk named Kim Dae-bi of Silla, and he ordered me to take the head of the Great Master of the Sixth Generation back to the East Sea to make offerings to it.
When Prefect Liu heard the report, he did not immediately sentence him to death. He personally went to Caoxi and asked the master's disciple Ling Tao:
How should this be judged?

Ling Tao said:ğŸ”½The master has already entered nirvana. He has no attachment to the body. The thief has already received the head. It is difficult to find him again. If you want to punish him, it should be in accordance with the law.
If we were to judge according to the laws of the country, the punishment would be death.
But because the Buddha's teachings are compassionate and treat enemies and friends equally, and moreover, he sought to make offerings, his crime can be forgiven.
Prefect Liu sighed in admiration:
Only now do I know that the Buddha's teachings are vast and great.
And so he pardoned him.
In the first year of the Shangyuan era, Suzong sent an envoy to request the master's robe and alms bowl, which were brought back to the palace for worship.

On the fifth day of the fifth month in the first year of the Yongtai era, Dezong dreamed that Chan Master Zhizhe of Nanyue requested his robe and alms bowl. Seven days later, he issued an edict to Prefect Yang Jian:
I had a dream in which Chan Master Neng requested the robe and kaá¹£Äya that transmitted the Dharma. I now send General Liu Chongjing to respectfully return them.
I consider them national treasures. You should properly enshrine them in your temple. Instruct the monks who personally received the teachings to strictly guard them and prevent any loss.
Later, when someone stole them, they were quickly recovered.
This happened four times.
Xuanzong posthumously bestowed the title of Chan Master of Great Insight, and his stupa was named Yuanhe Lingzhao.
The other events are recorded in the steles by Tang officials Wang Wei, Prefect Liu Zongyuan, and Prefect Liu Yuxi.
Recorded by monk Lingtao, who guarded the stupa.
